titleInfo.title: Plantation Diary, “The Plantation Record and Account Book No. 1, Suitable for a Force of 40 Hands or Under”

mods.abstract: p. 90-91: “Overseer’s Record of Births and Deaths of Negroes upon Pleasant Hill Plantation” and Record of Physician’s Visits to the Sick…” provides information about the health of the plantation’s slaves. Note: both Capell and his wife tended the slaves, as well as a local physician.
mods.note: Thomas Affleck was a native of Scotland who immigrated to the United States in 1832. He studied agriculture and general sciences and became editor of the Western Farmer and Gardener, a widely circulated agricultural periodical in the West. He managed the plantations of his wife and stepson in Adams County, Mississippi; established one of the first commercial nurseries in the South; and published widely on scientific and agricultural subjects. Affleck moved his home and nursery to Washington County, Texas, before the Civil War. He promoted immigration of white labor to the South after the war and died in 1868.
